abstract.t: Where-in it is necessary to commit to other parties the existence of a thing, the Concise Syndication is a stream or packet format for the purpose of sharing compactified Universally Unique IDentifiers that may be used as name tokens for further object resolution: concicse syndication provides framing and compactification, and guidelines for well known access patterns for interacting with valid CS names in the web environment.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Offering a minimal packet framing for Universally Unique IDentifiersRFC 4122, Concise Syndication conveys across packet or stream transports the presence of a resolvable UUID address other parties may use to be informed of the presence of any kind of information.
Concise Syndication also defines guidelines for well known services surrounding the token declarations being made, providing well defined means of inquiry pertaining to named tokens.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: Acknowledgements
section.t: This template was derived from an initial version written by Pekka Savola and contributed by him to the xml2rfc project.
This document origins, owing to the complexity of form and the need for a base template, began life ensnared in someone's s plan to make xml2rfc indispensable.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This memo includes no request to IANA.

All drafts are required to have an IANA considerations section (see Guidelines for Writing an IANA Considerations Section in RFCs for a guide). If the draft does not require IANA to do anything, the section contains an explicit statement that this is the case (as above). If there are no requirements for IANA, the section will be removed during conversion into an RFC by the RFC Editor.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: All drafts are required to have a security considerations section. See RFC 3552 for a guide.
